Costa Rica

Group E | North America

Chifrijo

A favorite bar snack of Los Ticos, chifrijo has is chips and salsa amped up by crispy pork and a classic Costa Rican condiment - Salsa Lizano. And if its not your new favorite sauce after this well, then not even Keylor Navas can save you.

Sonia Mendez Garcia shows us how to do it right. Coach suggests a boneless piece of pork belly, which will make for easy dicing later on in the recipe.

  • Time 2hrs
  • Makes 4
  • Difficulty Professional
  • Units Imperial Metric

Ingredients

  • 900g Pork belly
    2lb
    900g
    Pork belly
  • 2 tbsp Soy sauce
    2 tbsp
    2 tbsp
    Soy sauce
  • 2 Tomatoes
    2
    2
    Tomatoes
  • &frac12; Onion
    ½
    ½
    Onion diced
  • 1 Jalapeño pepper
    1
    1
    Jalapeño pepper deseeded, finely diced
  • 90g Coriander
    ¼ cup
    90g
    Coriander
  • 1 Lime
    1
    1
    Lime juiced
  • 3 tbsp Olive oil
    3 tbsp
    3 tbsp
    Olive oil
  • 1 clove Garlic
    1 clove
    1 clove
    Garlic minced
  • 1 piece Celery
    1 piece
    1 piece
    Celery
  • 1 tsp Cumin
    1 tsp
    1 tsp
    Cumin
  • 2 tbsp Salsa Linzano
    2 tbsp
    2 tbsp
    Salsa Linzano
  • 400g Black beans
    14oz
    400g
    Black beans canned
  • 475ml Vegetable oil
    2 cups
    475ml
    Vegetable oil
  • 140g Rice
    1 cup
    140g
    Rice
  • 350g Tortilla chips
    13oz
    350g
    Tortilla chips
  • 1 Avocado
    1
    1
    Avocado sliced
  • 1
    Preheat the oven to 500°F260°C. Season the pork belly with salt, pepper and soy sauce. Then place on a wire rack above lined baking sheet. Place in the oven for 10 minutes and then lower to 325°F160°C and leave for a further 90 minutes.
  • 2
    Meanwhile, make the pico de gallo by mixing together the tomatoes, onions, garlic, jalapeño pepper, coriander, lime juice and 1 tbsp of olive oil. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
  • 3
    On a low setting, heat 2 tbsp of olive oil in a sauce pan. Add garlic, celery and cook for 8 minutes. Then add cumin, Salsa Linzano, black beans with their liquid, and cover and cook for 20 minutes.
  • 4
    When cool, dice the pork belly into bite-size bits.
  • 5
    On a medium-high setting, heat the vegetable oil in a large saucepan. Once hot, in batches, add diced pieces of the pork until they turn a darker shade of brown. Place fried pieces of pork on a paper towel to dry.
  • 6
    In a small saucepan cook rice in 2 cups500ml of water - bring to a boil, lower the heat and cook with the lid on until rice is soft.
  • 7
    Serve over rice and tortilla chips. Layer with the beans, pork, pico de gallo and top with the avocado and an extra drizzle of Linzano.
